text: Patient: They didn’t tell me anything about it yet. I see Dr. G___ next week. Doctor: And you’re still taking the Enzalutamide? Patient: What’s that? Doctor: The Xtandi. Patient: Yes, I am, yes. Four pills a day. Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. They took blood last time, and ran some protocols and you were going to check on some numbers. Doctor: Anything new on your body that you’ve noticed that you want me to take a look at? Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds)

text: Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And in, in having an immune drug on board seems to make that whole thing work better. Um, I don’t have the answer for this vaccine radium combination, whether it’s going to do anything. But that’s, that’s the idea behind it is let’s bring these two things together. Uh, so, uh, again, if I had to say which one has the best chance of working for you right now is probably going to be a second hormone treatment. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and I think given where you are with the disease in the bone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I, I would probably lean towards something that I’d feel like we have a better chance of, of success. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: So continue with the Lupron, and every four months is what she gets us. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So what’s, what’s the deal at the (coughs) Doctor: Well, the trial is done. They are still analyzing the results. So there’s no final results, yet. Patient: From what? Doctor: From the study you were on. Right? That’s what you’re asking? Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA.

text: Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations. Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And you were in the hospital for seven days. Patient: Seven days. Yes and the numbers went from eight point six down to one point seven when it went out. Family Member: Because he was improving; results were uh coming in. You know kidneys back into you know. Patient: They were getting better everyday, yeah. text: Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. text: Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
